comments.body: The scary comment above sent me down a rabbit hole and I haven't found the end of it, but I'm satisfied that this gets called by the `[Feature:NodeUpgrade]` tests

Thanks for taking a look, I overlooked that comment. For existing uses (Linux -> NODE_INSTANCE_PREFIX) the change to get-template-name-from-version should be a no-op. I'm glad that this is covered by a test though, I'll check the upgrade tests after this gets merged to make sure I haven't broken anything.

I've been checking some test dashboards today to make sure this PR didn't break anything in the GCE cluster upgrade path. I don't see any notable failures here:

https://testgrid.k8s.io/sig-release-master-upgrade#gce-new-master-upgrade-cluster&width=20
https://testgrid.k8s.io/sig-release-master-upgrade#gce-new-master-upgrade-cluster-new-parallel&width=20

On https://testgrid.k8s.io/sig-release-master-upgrade#gce-new-master-upgrade-cluster-new&width=20 the first test run that would have included this PR (2116) didn't go so well - the whole run timed out and a bunch of tests were skipped. I'm hoping it's not related to this PR (the same thing happened a few days ago, run 2109), I'll take another look at the results tomorrow.

comments.body: Is this a copy paste from somewhere else? I had trouble finding exactly this elsewhere and expected it to match existing cluster setup scripts

This is not a copy paste. The existing scripts split creation between easy-rsa and cfssl for some reason and require creating *everything* in one swoop incluing the CA. We probably want to just move to cfssl for everything and consolidate all this (going to work on that in a followup). This usage seems fairly straightforward though.

comments.body: Careful about the permissions of key files. Not sure what we do elsewhere

https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/cluster/common.sh#L987-L996

comments.body: Do we need this in the `gce/` directory?
Yes.

Expounding a bit: I think paranoia here is valuable, and the check takes very little code, so I don't understand why we wouldn't check. I want to make it crystal clear that this isn't intended for anything else, so it's basically intended as an assert. It's also a comment to the reader, if they stumble into this file from just browsing around on github.

comments.body: Bangs misbehave in Bash
Not in this context

BTW, for reason why I pushed back: The bangs in here are actually safe because it's a non-interactive shell. ( https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/Interactive-Shell-Behavior.html ). They'd also be safe on your command line if you "set +histexpand" in your .profile, which honestly, is perfectly sane, because ! is one of the most dangerous behaviors the shell has.
